title: Policy Approaches to Increasing Urban Cycling: A Comparative Analysis
abstract: This comparative policy analysis examines cycling promotion strategies in 10 cities across 5 continents. The research identifies the relative effectiveness of infrastructure investments, financial incentives, educational campaigns, and regulatory approaches in increasing cycling mode share across diverse urban contexts.

title: Right to Mobility: Legal Frameworks for Equitable Transportation Access
journal: Harvard Civil Rights-Civil Liberties Law Review
abstract: This paper analyzes legal frameworks that establish mobility as a right rather than a privilege. Through examination of case law and statutory developments, we propose a comprehensive legal foundation for ensuring equitable access to sustainable transportation options for all communities.

title: Active Mobility and Public Health: A Systematic Review of Cycling's Impact on Population Health
abstract: This systematic review examines the relationship between active mobility, particularly cycling, and public health outcomes. The study synthesizes evidence from 50 international studies, demonstrating significant health benefits including reduced rates of cardiovascular disease, improved mental health, and lower healthcare costs.
